notes.title: Karl Marx: Class Conflict & Alienation
notes.content: Master Marx's materialist conception of history, class struggle, surplus value, and alienation; link to contemporary inequality and labor precarity.
keyTakeaways: Conflict over control of means of production drives social change.
Alienation: from product, process, species-being, and others.
Use for critical analysis of capitalist stratification in Pakistan.

resources.title: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy — Karl Marx
Crash Course — Karl Marx & Conflict Theory (Video)

notes.title: Émile Durkheim: Solidarity, Anomie & Suicide
notes.content: Cover mechanical vs. organic solidarity, social facts, anomie, and typology of suicide; apply to rapid change, extremism, and regulation/integration debates.
keyTakeaways: Social facts constrain individuals; cohesion via solidarity.
Anomie from normlessness during rapid change.
Use suicide typology conceptually (exam essays).

notes.title: Max Weber: Bureaucracy, Authority & Verstehen
notes.content: Differentiate traditional, charismatic, and legal-rational authority; bureaucracy's features and iron cage; interpretive understanding (Verstehen).
keyTakeaways: Bureaucracy = efficiency + rational-legal authority, but risks rigidity.
Power/legitimacy distinct; link to state and economy.
Use for public administration, education, and Pakistani civil service contexts.

notes.title: Ibn Khaldun: 'Asabiyyah, Rise–Decline Cycles
notes.content: Ground Islamic sociological heritage via Muqaddimah: group solidarity ('asabiyyah), state formation, and cyclical theory of dynasties.
keyTakeaways: 'Asabiyyah underpins state formation and decay.
Comparative links to Durkheim's solidarity & elite circulation.
Useful for Pakistan's kinship, biradari, tribal politics essays.

notes.title: Auguste Comte & Positivism
notes.content: Understand the Law of Three Stages and positivist method; contrast with interpretivist approaches.
keyTakeaways: Theological → Metaphysical → Positive stages.
Positivism prioritizes observation & prediction.
Exam often asks Comte vs. later sociologists.

notes.title: Symbolic Interactionism: Mead, Goffman & Cooley
notes.content: Micro-level focus on meanings, self, and interaction; Mead's 'I'/'Me', role-taking; Goffman's dramaturgy; Cooley's looking-glass self.
keyTakeaways: Society constructed through shared symbols & roles.
Great for analyzing identity, stigma, media, and everyday life.
Use examples from Pakistani urban youth/social media.

notes.title: Functionalism vs. Conflict vs. Interactionism (Compare & Apply)
notes.content: Triangulate macro vs. micro perspectives; apply to education, family, religion, media, and Pakistani social issues in essays.
keyTakeaways: Functionalism: order & equilibrium; Conflict: power & inequality; Interactionism: meanings & identity.
Use comparative table in exam answers.
Blend with local data (PSLM, PDHS).

notes.title: Research Designs: Qualitative, Quantitative & Mixed Methods
notes.content: Know when to use surveys, experiments, ethnography, and mixed designs; discuss validity, reliability, ethics, and ontology/epistemology.
keyTakeaways: Design matches question; justify trade-offs.
Discuss internal/external validity & reflexivity.
Ethics & consent crucial for Pakistan fieldwork.

resources.title: PMC — Quick Guide to Survey Research

notes.title: Sampling Techniques
notes.content: Differentiate probability vs. non-probability sampling; know SRS, stratified, cluster, systematic, snowball; justify in exam scenarios.
keyTakeaways: Sampling drives generalizability & bias.
Stratified sampling frequently examined.
Explain sample size logic & trade-offs.

notes.title: Variables & Levels of Measurement
notes.content: Master nominal, ordinal, interval/ratio; operationalization; hypothesis formation; measurement error.
keyTakeaways: Correct level → correct statistics.
Define IVs/DVs; avoid common mistakes.
Cite examples from Pakistan datasets.

notes.title: Survey vs. Experimental vs. Observational Methods
notes.content: Compare strengths/limits; causality vs. external validity; ethics; when Pakistan field constraints favor surveys or secondary data.
keyTakeaways: Experiments → causality; surveys → breadth.
Observational/secondary data → feasibility.
Always discuss biases & controls.

resources.title: Pressbooks — Doing Research on Social Problems

notes.title: Culture, Norms & Socialization
notes.content: Define culture, values, norms; agents of socialization; cultural change and lag.
keyTakeaways: Culture shapes identity, roles, and expectations.
Cultural lag: material vs. non-material change rates.
Link to education, media, and migration.

notes.title: Ethnocentrism, Xenocentrism & Cultural Relativism
notes.content: Define and illustrate ethnocentrism vs. xenocentrism; argue for cultural relativism in analysis with care.
keyTakeaways: Ethnocentrism biases research & policy.
Xenocentrism = preference for foreign cultural elements.
Relativism aids fair comparative analysis.

notes.title: Deviance & Social Control: Strain, Labeling, Control Theories
notes.content: Use Merton's strain, Becker's labeling, Hirschi's control; discuss formal/informal social control and Pakistan examples.
keyTakeaways: Deviance is socially constructed and patterned.
Labeling can amplify deviance via stigma.
Policy analysis: deterrence vs. rehabilitation.

notes.title: Social Stratification & Mobility (with Pakistan Examples)
notes.content: Discuss class, status, party; caste/biradari influences; mobility barriers.
keyTakeaways: Multidimensional inequality (class, education, gender).
Biradari & patronage affect political participation.
Use rural/urban, province-wise illustrations.

resources.title: PU Journal — Impact of Caste & Biradari on Voting (PDF)
White Rose Theses — Social Stratification in a Punjabi Village

notes.title: Family & Gender in Pakistan
notes.content: Patriarchal structures, changing family forms, gendered labor, and GBV trends.
keyTakeaways: Modernization reshapes family roles but kinship remains strong.
GBV persists; policy & social movements matter.
Use national surveys for evidence.

notes.title: Education & Social Change (Functionalist vs. Conflict in Pakistan)
notes.content: Credentialing, hidden curriculum, meritocracy debates; inequality of access and outcomes.
keyTakeaways: Functionalist: integration & skills; Conflict: reproduction of inequality.
Policy failures and regional disparities.
Cite OOSC figures and reforms.

notes.title: Religion & Society (Durkheim's Functional View)
notes.content: Religion as social cohesion and meaning; discuss pluralism, sectarianism, and civic implications in Pakistan.
keyTakeaways: Rituals reinforce collective conscience.
Religion can integrate or divide.
Use measured tone in essays; cite theory first.

notes.title: Demography: Fertility, Mortality, Migration (Pakistan Data)
notes.content: Use national surveys for fertility/mortality; internal & international migration impacts; DTM stages.
keyTakeaways: Demographic trends shape education, health, labor markets.
Migration redistributes skills and remittances.
Always include recent official stats.

resources.title: PBS — Population Census 2023 (Highlights)
resources.description: Official stats; see Census & PSLM sections

notes.title: Urbanization, Slums & Megacity Challenges (Pakistan)
notes.content: Analyze drivers of urban growth, informal settlements, service deficits, and policy responses.
keyTakeaways: Urban population share rising; infrastructure lags.
Informality and sprawl challenge governance.
Use city-specific examples (Karachi, Lahore, Islamabad).

notes.title: Poverty & Inequality Trends (Current Affairs Angle)
notes.content: Track poverty headcount swings, inflation shocks, and social protection debates; link to class and policy frameworks.
keyTakeaways: Recent macro shocks reversed poverty gains.
Use credible data & cautious interpretation.
Connect to Marx/Weber analyses in essays.

notes.title: Pakistan Institutions: Feudalism, Biradari & Patronage
notes.content: Critically assess land, kinship, and patronage structures and their political effects.
keyTakeaways: Feudal legacies intersect with modern politics.
Biradari shapes mobilization and voting.
Support with district/province case studies.

resources.title: PIDE/ PDR — Poverty, Feudalism & Land Reform
PU — Feudalism in Pakistan: Myth or Reality (PDF)

notes.title: Health, Drugs & Juvenile Justice (Pakistan Evidence)
notes.content: Use credible reports on substance use, youth, prisons, and juvenile justice for applied questions.
keyTakeaways: UNODC provides trend baselines; new national survey 2022–24 launched.
Juvenile justice implementation gaps persist.
Link family/community reintegration to control theory.

resources.title: UNODC — National Drug Use Survey 2022–24 (Launch Note)
UNODC — World Drug Report 2025 (Key Findings PDF)

notes.title: Exam Strategy: Official FPSC Syllabus, Books & Past Papers
notes.content: Anchor prep to official outlines; map your notes to FPSC taxonomy; practice with recent papers.
keyTakeaways: Always align with latest FPSC syllabus PDF.
Skim recommended books list; combine with OERs.
Practice time-bound answers using past papers.
